address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico
Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

abstract.para: These files contain hourly measurements of air temperature, relative humidity, windspeed, solar radiation, vapor pressure, and soil temperature and moisture for an array of automated weather stations at the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge and some satellite sites.

keywordSet.keywordThesaurus: obfs.84.4Sevilleta Meteorological DataJamesGoszDepartment of Biology, University of New MexicoAlbuquerqueNew Mexico87131USA1-505-277-2265jgosz@sevilleta.unm.eduPrincipal InvestigatorDougMooreDepartment of Biology, University of New MexicoAlbuquerqueNew Mexico87131U1-505-277-6328dmoore@sevilleta.unm.eduData ContactDougMooreContent ProviderKristin VanderbiltMetadata Provider(NM) Sevilleta Field StationOriginatorOrganization of Biological Field StationsOriginatorThese files contain hourly measurements of air temperature, relative humidity, windspeed, solar radiation, vapor pressure, and soil temperature and moisture for an array of automated weather stations at the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge and some satellite sites.Paragraph 2zooplanktonVan Dorn samplingpopulation surveyfictitious sample dataGreat LakesTest thesaurusobtain permission from originator(s)Select type of medium here.obfs.83.2describes access control rules forobfs.84.4obfs.83.2provides access control rules forobfs.83.223JUL198703Jan1991107.03106.5234.3834.22rnrvcommonrn1rv1common1

attribute.attributeDefinition: Identification number of plant
This is a six-letter code. For thecomplete species name, please see file BCISP.txt.
X coordinate within the plot, numbers go from west to east
Y coordinate within the plot, numbers go from south to north
Tree diameter at breast height

codeDefinition.definition: Indicates that the plant had a dbh of 10 mm or greater in a previous census, then probably broke off and is still alive in this census, but does not yet measure 10 mm (resprout)
indicates that the plant is dead
the plant has not yet entered the census

attribute.attributeDefinition: Code tells if stem is alive or dead. If alive, incudes dbh size as greater or smaller than 1 cm dbh

codeDefinition.definition: alive and above 1cm dbh (diameter at breast height)
alive but below 1 cm dbh (diameter at breast height)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Indicates whether there was a change in point of measure (POM). A change in POM was not consistently recorded in the field data sheets, except in the case of the"big" trees with buttresses. This variable was added into the database recently, using rules that were recently devised. All stems with dbh>=10mm were given a POM of 1 the first time they entered a census. If the plant was measured at a new height or stem in the next census, POM was increased to the next number. This happened for trees with buttresses if the measurement was taken above the buttress, for resprouts, for trees with deformities at 1.3m, and for multiple stems that lost the largest stem.

codeDefinition.definition: All stems with dbh>=10mm were given a POM of 1 the first time they entered a census

If the plant was measured at a new height or stem in the next census, POM was increased to the next number. This happened for trees with buttresses if the measurement was taken above the buttress, for resprouts, for trees with deformities at 1.3m, and for multiple stems that lost the largest stem.
0the stem had not yet entered the census, tree died or missing dbh

attribute.attributeDefinition: These codes indicate condition of the tree. Unfortunately, different codes were used over the censuses, and sometimes the same code could mean different things in different censuses. In 1985, codes were usually entered in pairs, so a letter can take different meanings depending on what the previous letter was. Codes were consistent for the 90 and 95 censuses.

These codes indicate condition of the tree. Unfortunately, different codes were used over the censuses, and sometimes the same code could mean different things in different censuses. In 1985, codes were usually entered in pairs, so a letter can take different meanings depending on what the previous letter was. Codes were consistent for the 90 and 95 censuses.

In 1985, codes were usually entered in pairs, so a letter can take different meanings depending on what the previous letter was. Codes were consistent for the 90 and 95 censuses.

In 1985, codes were usually entered in pairs, so a letter can take different meanings depending on what the previous letter was. Codes were consistent for the 90 and 95 censuses.
Number of Stems at 1.3m, most will have 1 stem. Please refer to the multiple stem files for all multiple stem measurements (m80, m85, m90, m95)
